article:
Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves

Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves is a 2023 American fantasy adventure film directed by Jonathan Goldstein and John Francis Daley, from a screenplay by Goldstein, Daley, and Michael Gilio. The film is based on the classic tabletop role-playing game Dungeons & Dragons, developed by Gary Gygax and Dave Arneson. The movie follows a group of misfits as they embark on a thrilling journey filled with danger, magic, and camaraderie.

#Plot

The film takes place in the Forgotten Realms, a fantasy world filled with mythical creatures, legendary heroes, and ancient magic. The story revolves around Edgin Darvis (Chris Pine), a charismatic thief and scoundrel who is determined to pull off the heist of a lifetime. Edgin is joined by a motley crew of adventurers, each with their unique skills and personalities. There's Holga Kilgore (Michelle Rodriguez), a battle-hardened warrior with a penchant for violence; Xenk Yendar (Regé-Jean Page), a charming and cunning rogue; Doric (Sophia Lillis), a half-orc who is both fierce and gentle; and Simon Aumar (Justice Smith), a bumbling but lovable wizard.

As the group navigates the complex web of intrigue and deception, they find themselves entangled in a sinister plot that threatens the very fabric of their world. Along the way, they must confront their own demons, forge unexpected alliances, and learn to trust each other if they hope to survive. With action-packed sequences, witty humor, and heartfelt moments of vulnerability, Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves is a thrilling adventure that will keep audiences on the edge of their seats.

#Cast

The film boasts an impressive ensemble cast, featuring some of the most talented actors in the industry today.

* Chris Pine as Edgin Darvis
* Michelle Rodriguez as Holga Kilgore
* Regé-Jean Page as Xenk Yendar
* Sophia Lillis as Doric
* Justice Smith as Simon Aumar
* Hugh Grant as Forge Fitzwilliam
* Chloe Coleman as Sophie

#Production

##Development and casting

Development on the film began in 2015, when Paramount Pictures acquired the rights to adapt the Dungeons & Dragons franchise into a feature film. Goldstein and Daley were brought on board to write and direct the project, with Jeremy Latcham and Brian Goldner serving as producers. Casting began in 2020, with Chris Pine being the first to join the project. The rest of the cast was announced over the course of the next year, with Michelle Rodriguez, Regé-Jean Page, and Sophia Lillis rounding out the main ensemble.

##Writing

Goldstein and Daley worked closely with Michael Gilio to develop the screenplay, drawing inspiration from the classic Dungeons & Dragons campaign modules and the Forgotten Realms setting. The writers aimed to create a story that would appeal to both fans of the game and newcomers alike, balancing action, humor, and heart. The script went through several drafts before the final version was locked in.

##Filming and visual effects

Principal photography began in April 2021 and wrapped in August of the same year. The film was shot on location in Iceland and Northern Ireland, with additional scenes filmed in the United Kingdom. The visual effects were handled by Weta Digital, with a team of over 500 artists and technicians working on the project. The film's action sequences, creature designs, and magical effects were all created using a combination of practical and CGI techniques.

#Music

The original score for the film was composed by John Powell, who is known for his work on the Bourne and How to Train Your Dragon franchises. The soundtrack features a mix of orchestral and choral pieces, incorporating themes and motifs inspired by the world of Dungeons & Dragons. The score was recorded at Abbey Road Studios in London, with a 90-piece orchestra and a 60-voice choir.

#Release

##Theatrical

Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves was released in theaters on March 31, 2023, in the United States and United Kingdom. The film received a wide release, playing on over 4,000 screens in the US and 1,000 screens in the UK.

##Home media

The film was released on digital platforms on May 30, 2023, and on Blu-ray and DVD on June 6, 2023. The home media release includes a range of bonus features, including deleted scenes, behind-the-scenes featurettes, and a commentary track with the directors and cast.

#Marketing

##Promotion

The marketing campaign for the film began in earnest in December 2022, with the release of the first trailer. The trailer was met with widespread enthusiasm, generating over 10 million views on YouTube within the first 24 hours. The film's social media accounts were launched shortly thereafter, featuring character posters, behind-the-scenes images, and cast interviews. Fans were also encouraged to share their own Dungeons & Dragons-inspired artwork and cosplay using the hashtag #DnD.

##Tie-in literature and merchandise

To coincide with the film's release, Wizards of the Coast published a tie-in novelization of the story, written by E.K. Johnston. The book was released on March 14, 2023, and features an exclusive introduction by Goldstein and Daley. A range of merchandise, including toys, apparel, and accessories, was also released, featuring the film's characters and logo.

#Reception

##Box office

Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves opened to strong box office numbers, grossing over $60 million in its opening weekend in the US. The film went on to gross over $200 million worldwide, making it a commercial success.

##Critical response

The film received generally positive reviews from critics, with an approval rating of 82% on Rotten Tomatoes. The consensus reads: "Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves is a fun, action-packed adventure that will delight fans of the game and newcomers alike." The film also received praise for its cast, with many critics noting the chemistry between the leads.

##Accolades

The film was nominated for several awards, including a Saturn Award for Best Fantasy Film and a Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Action Movie.

#Future

##Possible sequel

In April 2023, Goldstein and Daley confirmed that a sequel to the film was in development, with the same cast and crew set to return. The sequel is currently in the early stages of development, with a script being written by the directors and Michael Gilio.

##Spin-off television series

In May 2023, it was announced that a spin-off television series based on the film was in development, with Paramount+ serving as the production partner. The series will follow a new group of characters as they navigate the world of Dungeons & Dragons.

#Notes

* The film's title, Honor Among Thieves, is a reference to the classic Dungeons & Dragons module of the same name.
* The film's score was recorded using a combination of traditional orchestral instruments and unconventional sounds, such as a 100-year-old glass harmonica.
* The film's visual effects team created over 1,000 visual effects shots for the film, including creature designs, action sequences, and magical effects.

*None*

article:
2021–22 Premier League

The 2021–22 Premier League was the 30th season of the Premier League, the top English professional league for association football clubs, since its establishment in 1992. The season began on 13 August 2021 and concluded on 22 May 2022.

Summary
--------

### The race for first place

The 2021–22 Premier League season saw a closely contested title race between Manchester City, Liverpool, and Chelsea. Manchester City eventually won their fourth Premier League title in five years, finishing one point ahead of Liverpool. Chelsea finished third, 19 points behind the champions.

### Newcastle takeover

In October 2021, the Premier League approved the takeover of Newcastle United by a consortium backed by Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund. The deal was worth £305 million, with the consortium purchasing an 80% stake in the club. The takeover marked a significant change in the ownership of the club, with the new owners pledging to invest in the team and improve the club's infrastructure.

### COVID-19 outbreaks force postponements

The 2021–22 Premier League season was affected by COVID-19 outbreaks, with several matches postponed due to positive cases among players and staff. The outbreaks led to a congested fixture list, with some teams playing multiple matches in a short period.

### Abramovich sanctions

In March 2022, Chelsea owner Roman Abramovich was sanctioned by the UK government due to his alleged ties to Russian President Vladimir Putin. The sanctions froze Abramovich's assets, including his stake in Chelsea, and prevented the club from selling tickets or merchandise. The club was eventually sold to a consortium led by Todd Boehly in May 2022.

### Final day climax

The final day of the season saw a dramatic conclusion to the title race, with Manchester City coming from behind to beat Aston Villa 3-2 and win the title. Liverpool beat Wolverhampton Wanderers 3-1, but it was not enough to overtake Manchester City.

#### Title

Manchester City won their fourth Premier League title in five years, finishing one point ahead of Liverpool. The title was won on the final day of the season, with Manchester City coming from behind to beat Aston Villa 3-2.

#### Relegation

Norwich City, Watford, and Everton were relegated to the Championship, finishing 20th, 19th, and 18th respectively.

#### Champions League, Europa League and Conference League spots

Manchester City, Liverpool, Chelsea, and Tottenham Hotspur qualified for the Champions League, while Arsenal and Manchester United qualified for the Europa League. West Ham United qualified for the Europa Conference League.

Other teams
------------

Teams like Leicester City, Brighton & Hove Albion, and Crystal Palace had solid seasons, finishing 8th, 9th, and 12th respectively.

article:
2023 Gabonese coup d'état

The 2023 Gabonese coup d'état was a military seizure of power that took place in Gabon on August 30, 2023. The coup led to the overthrow of President Ali Bongo Ondimba, who had been in power since 2009.

#Background

Gabon, a country located in Central Africa, has a history of authoritarian rule and political instability. The country gained independence from France in 1960, and since then, it has been ruled by the Bongo family, with Omar Bongo serving as president from 1967 until his death in 2009. His son, Ali Bongo Ondimba, succeeded him and has been in power ever since.

##2023 elections

In August 2023, Gabon held presidential elections, which were widely seen as a sham. The elections were marked by allegations of voter suppression, ballot stuffing, and other forms of electoral malfeasance. President Ali Bongo Ondimba was declared the winner, with 64% of the vote, but the opposition rejected the results, claiming that the election was rigged.

#Coup

The coup was launched on August 30, 2023, by a group of military officers who were dissatisfied with the government's handling of the economy and the country's political situation. The military officers, who were led by General Brice Oligui, seized control of key government buildings, including the presidential palace, and announced that they had taken power.

##Events

The coup was carried out with relative ease, as the government's security forces were quickly overwhelmed by the military. President Ali Bongo Ondimba was nowhere to be found, and it was later reported that he had fled the country. The military officers declared a state of emergency and announced that they would be forming a new government.

##Arrests of Ali Bongo and other officials

On August 31, 2023, it was announced that President Ali Bongo Ondimba had been arrested, along with several other high-ranking government officials. The officials were accused of corruption and mismanagement of the country's economy. General Brice Oligui announced that the officials would be put on trial for their alleged crimes.

##Proclamation of Brice Oligui as interim president

On September 1, 2023, General Brice Oligui was proclaimed interim president of Gabon. Oligui announced that he would be forming a new government and that he would oversee the country's transition to democracy. He also promised to root out corruption and to improve the country's economy.

#Aftermath

The coup was widely condemned by the international community, but it was also seen as a opportunity for Gabon to transition to democracy.

##Formation of a new government

General Brice Oligui formed a new government, which was composed of military officers and civilians. The government was tasked with overseeing the country's transition to democracy and with implementing economic reforms. The government also announced that it would be holding new elections within six months.

##Bongo's release

On September 15, 2023, it was announced that President Ali Bongo Ondimba had been released from detention. Bongo was allowed to return to his home, where he was placed under house arrest. The government announced that Bongo would be put on trial for corruption and mismanagement of the country's economy.

#Reactions

The coup was widely condemned by the international community, but it was also seen as a opportunity for Gabon to transition to democracy.

##Domestic

The coup was met with widespread support from the Gabonese people, who were tired of the Bongo family's authoritarian rule. Many people saw the coup as a chance for the country to transition to democracy and to improve its economy.

##International

The international community was quick to condemn the coup, with many countries calling for the restoration of democratic rule. The African Union and the European Union both issued statements condemning the coup and calling for the release of President Ali Bongo Ondimba.

article:
Matty Healy

Matthew Timothy Healy, known professionally as Matty Healy, is a British singer, songwriter, and record producer. He is best known as the lead vocalist and guitarist of the English pop rock band The 1975.

# Early life

Matty Healy was born on April 8, 1989, in London, England, to actors Denise Welch and Tim Healy. He has a brother, Louis Healy, who is also an actor. 2022 French Legislative Election

The 2022 French legislative election was held on 12 and 19 June 2022 to elect the 577 members of the 16th National Assembly of the French Fifth Republic. The election was the first to be held after the 2022 presidential election, in which Emmanuel Macron was re-elected for a second term as President of France.

# Background

The 2022 legislative election was the first to be held under the presidency of Emmanuel Macron, who had been elected for a second term in the presidential election held in April 2022. The election took place in the aftermath of the presidential election, in which Macron had defeated Marine Le Pen of the National Rally (RN) by a margin of 58.55% to 41.45%.

The legislative election was seen as a key test for Macron's presidency, as he sought to secure a majority in the National Assembly to implement his policies. The election was also seen as an opportunity for the opposition parties to challenge Macron's dominance and to present alternative policies to the French people.

# Electoral System

The French legislative election uses a two-round system to elect the members of the National Assembly. In the first round, voters in each constituency elect a candidate to represent them in the National Assembly. If a candidate receives more than 50% of the valid votes cast in the constituency, they are elected in the first round. If no candidate receives more than 50% of the valid votes, a second round is held between the top two candidates, with the candidate receiving the most votes being elected.

# Dates

The first round of the legislative election was held on 12 June 2022, with the second round being held on 19 June 2022. The official campaign period began on 30 May 2022 and ended on 10 June 2022 for the first round, and on 13 June 2022 for the second round.

# Major Parties and Alliances

The main parties and alliances that contested the 2022 legislative election were:

* La République En Marche! (LREM), the party founded by Emmanuel Macron in 2016, which was seeking to retain its majority in the National Assembly.
* National Rally (RN), led by Marine Le Pen, which was seeking to increase its representation in the National Assembly and to present a challenge to Macron's presidency.
* The Socialist Party (PS), which was seeking to rebuild its representation in the National Assembly after a poor performance in the 2017 legislative election.
* The Republicans (LR), which was seeking to increase its representation in the National Assembly and to present a challenge to Macron's presidency from the right.
* La France Insoumise (LFI), a left-wing party led by Jean-Luc Mélenchon, which was seeking to increase its representation in the National Assembly and to present a challenge to Macron's presidency from the left.

## Deputies not Standing for Reelection

A number of deputies chose not to stand for re-election in the 2022 legislative election, including several high-profile members of the National Assembly. These included:

* François de Rugy, the former President of the National Assembly, who announced that he would not be standing for re-election due to his involvement in a scandal over his use of public funds.
* Richard Ferrand, the leader of the LREM group in the National Assembly, who announced that he would not be standing for re-election due to his involvement in a scandal over his use of public funds.
* Olivier Véran, the former Minister of Health, who announced that he would not be standing for re-election in order to focus on his work as a doctor.

# Opinion Polls

The opinion polls in the run-up to the 2022 legislative election suggested that La République En Marche! would retain its majority in the National Assembly, but that the party would face a challenge from the opposition parties. The polls also suggested that the National Rally would increase its representation in the National Assembly, and that La France Insoumise would also make gains.

# Results

## First Round

The first round of the legislative election was held on 12 June 2022. The results of the first round showed that La République En Marche! had won the most votes, with 25.75% of the valid votes cast. The National Rally had come second, with 19.05% of the valid votes, followed by La France Insoumise, which had won 13.02% of the valid votes.

## Second Round

The second round of the legislative election was held on 19 June 2022. The results of the second round showed that La République En Marche! had won 245 seats in the National Assembly, followed by the National Rally, which had won 89 seats. La France Insoumise had won 72 seats, while the Socialist Party had won 27 seats.

article:
Halloween Ends is a 2022 American slasher film directed by David Gordon Green and co-written with Paul Brad Logan, Chris Bernier, and Danny McBride. The film is the third installment in the Halloween trilogy, following Halloween (2018) and Halloween Kills (2020).

#Plot

Halloween Ends takes place four years after the events of Halloween Kills. Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis) has written a memoir about her experiences with Michael Myers and is living with her granddaughter Allyson (Andi Matichak). Laurie is trying to move on from the trauma of her past and find peace. However, a new threat emerges in the form of Corey Cunningham (Rohan Campbell), a young man who becomes obsessed with Michael Myers and seeks to take on his mantle.

As Corey becomes more and more unstable, he begins to terrorize Haddonfield, Illinois, and Laurie is forced to confront her past once again. Along the way, she must also confront her own mortality and the legacy she will leave behind. The film builds towards a final confrontation between Laurie and Corey, with the fate of Haddonfield hanging in the balance.

#Cast

* Jamie Lee Curtis as Laurie Strode
* Andi Matichak as Allyson Nelson
* Rohan Campbell as Corey Cunningham
* Will Patton as Deputy Frank Hawkins
* Kyle Richards as Lindsey Wallace
* James Jude Courtney as Michael Myers

#Production

##Development

The development of Halloween Ends began shortly after the release of Halloween Kills. Director David Gordon Green and his co-writers began brainstorming ideas for the final installment of the trilogy. The film was initially intended to be a more intimate, character-driven story that would focus on Laurie's emotional journey.

##Writing

The screenplay for Halloween Ends was written by David Gordon Green, Paul Brad Logan, Chris Bernier, and Danny McBride. The writers drew inspiration from the original Halloween film, as well as other horror classics. They also explored themes of trauma, mortality, and the cyclical nature of violence.

##Casting

The cast of Halloween Ends includes several returning actors from the previous two films, including Jamie Lee Curtis, Andi Matichak, and Will Patton. Rohan Campbell was cast as Corey Cunningham, the film's new villain. Campbell was chosen for his ability to bring a sense of vulnerability and intensity to the role.

##Filming

Principal photography for Halloween Ends took place in the fall of 2021. The film was shot on location in Georgia, with some scenes also filmed in California. The production team used a combination of practical and digital effects to create the film's horror sequences.

##Post-production

Post-production on Halloween Ends began in early 2022. The film's editor, Tim Alverson, worked closely with director David Gordon Green to shape the final cut of the film. The sound design and visual effects teams also played a key role in enhancing the film's horror elements.

##Music

The score for Halloween Ends was composed by Cody Carpenter and Daniel Davies. The soundtrack features a mix of electronic and orchestral elements, and incorporates themes from the original Halloween score.

#Release

Halloween Ends was released in theaters on October 14, 2022. The film was distributed by Universal Pictures and Blumhouse Productions.

##Home media

Halloween Ends was released on digital platforms on November 15, 2022. The film was also released on DVD and Blu-ray on December 27, 2022.

#Reception

##Audience viewership

Halloween Ends was a commercial success, grossing over $130 million worldwide. The film played to packed theaters on its opening weekend, with many fans eager to see the final installment of the trilogy.

##Box office

Halloween Ends opened at number one at the box office, with a domestic opening weekend of $40.1 million. The film went on to gross over $64 million in the United States and over $66 million internationally.

##Critical response

Halloween Ends received mixed reviews from critics. Some praised the film's emotional depth and performances, while others found it to be overly reliant on nostalgia and retreading familiar territory. The film holds a 53% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 242 reviews.

##Accolades

Halloween Ends was nominated for several awards, including a Saturn Award for Best Horror Film and a Fangoria Chainsaw Award for Best Wide-Release Film.

#Future

Halloween Ends marks the final installment of the Halloween trilogy. However, it is likely that the Halloween franchise will continue in some form in the future. Universal Pictures has expressed interest in developing new Halloween projects, and Jamie Lee Curtis has stated that she would be open to reprising her role as Laurie Strode in a potential spin-off or sequel.

* Horror film

#Notes

* The film's script was influenced by the true crime podcast "My Favorite Murder".
* Jamie Lee Curtis performed many of her own stunts in the film.

article:
Banjska Attack

The Banjska attack was a major military conflict that occurred on August 12, 2001, in the Banjska village of Kosovo, near the border with Serbia. The attack was carried out by a group of Albanian separatists against a Yugoslav army outpost, resulting in significant casualties on both sides. The incident marked a turning point in the Kosovo conflict, leading to increased tensions between Kosovo Albanians and the Yugoslav government, as well as international efforts to resolve the crisis.

#Background

The Kosovo conflict had its roots in the early 1990s, as tensions rose between Kosovo Albanians and the Yugoslav government. Kosovo, a province in southern Serbia, had a predominantly Albanian population, which sought greater autonomy or independence from Yugoslavia. The Yugoslav government, under the leadership of Slobodan Milošević, responded to these demands with force, leading to a series of violent clashes and human rights abuses.

In 1999, the situation escalated into a full-scale war between the Yugoslav army and the Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA), an Albanian separatist group. The conflict ended with the intervention of NATO forces, which bombed Yugoslav military targets and forced the withdrawal of Yugoslav troops from Kosovo.

However, the region remained volatile, with tensions between Kosovo Albanians and the Yugoslav government persisting. The Banjska attack was a manifestation of this ongoing conflict.

#Attack

##Weaponry

The attackers, armed with small arms, mortars, and rocket-propelled grenades, launched a surprise assault on the Yugoslav army outpost in Banjska. The outpost was lightly defended, with only a few dozen soldiers stationed there.

##Attackers

The attackers were identified as members of the Albanian National Army (ANA), a separatist group that had emerged in the aftermath of the Kosovo war. The ANA was comprised of former KLA fighters and other Albanian nationalists who sought to continue the armed struggle for independence.

##Casualties

The attack resulted in significant casualties on both sides. According to reports, 14 Yugoslav soldiers were killed, while several others were wounded. The ANA also suffered losses, with estimates suggesting that between 5-10 attackers were killed.

#Aftermath

##Resolutions

###Kosovo and Albania

The Banjska attack led to widespread condemnation from Kosovo Albanian leaders, who distanced themselves from the ANA and its actions. The Kosovo government, led by President Ibrahim Rugova, issued a statement denouncing the attack and calling for calm.

In Albania, the government also condemned the attack, with Prime Minister Ilir Meta stating that Albania would not support any actions that could destabilize the region.

###European Union

The European Union (EU) responded to the attack by calling for restraint and calm. The EU's High Representative for Common Foreign and Security Policy, Javier Solana, issued a statement urging all parties to refrain from violence and to engage in dialogue.

##Serbian state involvement

The Yugoslav government, led by President Vojislav Koštunica, responded to the attack by accusing Kosovo Albanian leaders of complicity in the ANA's actions. The government also announced plans to increase its military presence in the region, citing concerns about the security situation.

##Serbian military buildup and base construction

In the aftermath of the Banjska attack, the Yugoslav army began to build up its military presence in the region. The army constructed new bases and checkpoints, and increased the number of troops stationed in Kosovo.

#Reactions

##Kosovo

The Banjska attack was widely condemned by Kosovo Albanian leaders, who saw it as a setback for their efforts to achieve independence through peaceful means. The attack also led to increased tensions between Kosovo Albanians and the Yugoslav government, with many Albanians fearing that the attack would be used as a pretext for further repression.

##Serbia

In Serbia, the attack was seen as a provocation by Albanian separatists, and was widely condemned by the government and media. The attack also led to increased nationalist sentiment, with many Serbs calling for tougher action against Kosovo Albanians.

##International

The international community responded to the Banjska attack with concern, calling for calm and restraint. The United Nations Security Council issued a statement condemning the attack and urging all parties to engage in dialogue.

The Banjska attack marked a turning point in the Kosovo conflict, highlighting the ongoing tensions between Kosovo Albanians and the Yugoslav government. The attack also underscored the need for a peaceful resolution to the conflict, and led to increased international efforts to find a solution.

article:
Salman Rushdie

Sir Ahmad Salman Rushdie is a British Indian novelist and essayist. His work often explores themes of identity, culture, and politics, blending elements of magical realism, fantasy, and historical fiction. Born in Bombay, India, Rushdie moved to England at a young age and later became a prominent figure in the literary world. His novels have been translated into numerous languages, and he has received numerous awards and honors for his contributions to literature.

#Early life and education

Salman Rushdie was born on June 19, 1947, in Bombay, India, to Anis Ahmed Rushdie and Negin Bhatt. His father was a Cambridge-educated lawyer, and his mother was a teacher. Rushdie's family moved to England when he was 14 years old, and he attended Rugby School in Warwickshire. He later studied history at King's College, Cambridge, where he earned a Master of Arts degree.

#Career

##Copywriter

Before becoming a full-time novelist, Rushdie worked as a copywriter for the advertising agency Ogilvy & Mather in London. During this time, he wrote advertising campaigns for various clients, including the famous "Naughty but Nice" slogan for the cream cake brand Mr. Kipling.

##Literary works

###Early works and literary breakthrough, 1975–1987

Rushdie's first novel, "Grimus," was published in 1975 to moderate success. However, it was his second novel, "Midnight's Children," published in 1981, that brought him international recognition and critical acclaim. The novel tells the story of India's transition to independence and the subsequent struggles of its people. "Midnight's Children" won the Booker Prize in 1981, catapulting Rushdie to literary stardom.

###The Satanic Verses and Haroun and the Sea of Stories, 1988–1990

Rushdie's fourth novel, "The Satanic Verses," was published in 1988 and sparked widespread controversy. The novel explores themes of identity, culture, and politics, and includes a fictionalized account of the life of the Prophet Muhammad. The book was banned in several countries, and Rushdie was forced to go into hiding due to death threats and a fatwā issued by Ayatollah Khomeini.

During this time, Rushdie wrote "Haroun and the Sea of Stories," a children's novel that explores the power of storytelling and imagination. The book was published in 1990 and has since become a classic of children's literature.

###Further works, 1990s–2000s

Rushdie's subsequent novels include "The Moor's Last Sigh" (1995), "The Ground Beneath Her Feet" (1999), and "Fury" (2001). These novels explore themes of identity, culture, and politics, and are characterized by their complex characters and magical realist storytelling.

###Later works, novels, and essays, 2015–2024

Rushdie's more recent works include "Two Years Eight Months and Twenty-Eight Nights" (2015), a novel that explores the intersection of mythology and reality, and "The Golden House" (2017), a novel that explores the lives of a wealthy family in New York City. He has also published several collections of essays, including "Step Across This Line" (2002) and "Languages of Truth" (2021).

##Critical reception

Rushdie's work has been widely praised by critics and scholars. His novels have been translated into numerous languages, and he has received numerous awards and honors for his contributions to literature. However, his work has also been subject to controversy and criticism, particularly with regards to his depiction of sensitive cultural and religious themes.

##Academic and other activities

Rushdie has taught at several universities, including Emory University and New York University. He has also been a fellow at the Royal Society of Literature and the American Academy of Arts and Letters. In 2014, he was appointed as the Distinguished Writer in Residence at New York University.

##Film and television

Rushdie's work has been adapted into several films and television shows. His novel "Midnight's Children" was adapted into a film in 2012, directed by Deepa Mehta. He has also written screenplays for several films and television shows, including the HBO series "The Next Big Thing."

#The Satanic Verses and the fatwā

##Failed assassination attempt (1989)

In 1989, Rushdie was the target of a failed assassination attempt by Mustafa Mahmoud Mazeh, a Palestinian nationalist. Mazeh had been hired by the Iranian government to kill Rushdie, but he was unable to carry out the attack.

###Hezbollah's comments (2006)

In 2006, Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah commented on the fatwā against Rushdie, stating that it was still in effect and that Rushdie was a "dead man."

##International Guerillas (1990)

In 1990, a group of Iranian students calling themselves the "International Guerillas" attempted to assassinate Rushdie. The group was linked to the Iranian government and had been responsible for several other attacks on Iranian dissidents.

##Al-Qaeda hit list (2010)

In 2010, Rushdie was included on an Al-Qaeda hit list of individuals to be targeted for assassination. The list was published in the Al-Qaeda magazine "Inspire."

##Jaipur Literature Festival (2012)

In 2012, Rushdie was scheduled to appear at the Jaipur Literature Festival in India. However, he was forced to cancel his appearance due to death threats and protests from Muslim groups.

##Chautauqua attack (2022)

On August 12, 2022, Rushdie was attacked on stage at the Chautauqua Institution in New York. The attacker, Hadi Matar, stabbed Rushdie multiple times and also attacked the event moderator, Henry Reese. Rushdie suffered serious injuries but survived the attack.

#Awards, honours, and recognition

##Knighthood

Rushdie was knighted in 2007 for his services to literature. The knighthood was awarded by Queen Elizabeth II and was seen as a recognition of Rushdie's contributions to literature and his role as a prominent public intellectual.

#Religious and political beliefs

##Religious background

Rushdie was born into a Muslim family, but he has stated that he is an atheist. He has been critical of religious extremism and has spoken out against the use of religion to justify violence and oppression.

##Political background

###UK politics

Rushdie has been a vocal critic of British politics and has spoken out against the Labour Party's handling of issues such as immigration and terrorism.

###US politics

Rushdie has also been critical of US politics, particularly with regards to the country's handling of issues such as terrorism and civil liberties.

###Against religious extremism

Rushdie has been a vocal critic of religious extremism, particularly with regards to Islam. He has spoken out against the use of religion to justify violence and oppression, and has argued that Islam needs to be reformed to be compatible with modern values.

###South Asian politics and Kashmir

Rushdie has also been involved in South Asian politics, particularly with regards to the issue of Kashmir. He has spoken out against Indian government policies in Kashmir and has argued that the region needs greater autonomy.

#Personal life

Rushdie has been married four times and has two children. He currently lives in New York City and is a professor at New York University.

#Bibliography

##Novels

* "Midnight's Children" (1981)
* "Shame" (1983)

* "Homeless by Choice" (1992)

* "The Languages of Truth: Essays 2003-2020" (2021)

##Memoirs

* "Joseph Anton: A Memoir" (2012)

The Eras Tour was announced on November 1, 2022, via Swift's social media accounts. The tour was initially scheduled to begin in the United States and Canada, with international dates announced later.

## US dates

2022 Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly Election

The 2022 Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly election was held on November 12, 2022, to elect 68 members of the Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly. The results were announced on December 8, 2022. The election was the fourteenth assembly election in the state since its formation in 1966.

#Background

The Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly has 68 constituencies, each representing a district or a part of a district. The term of the 13th Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly was set to end on January 8, 2023. The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) had a majority in the outgoing assembly, with Jai Ram Thakur as the Chief Minister.

##Bypolls and defections

Since the 2017 Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly election, there have been several by-elections and defections. In 2019, the Mandi Lok Sabha constituency by-election was held, in which the BJP won. In 2021, the Fatehpur and Arki constituencies by-elections were held, in which the BJP and the Indian National Congress (INC) won, respectively. There have been several defections from the INC to the BJP, including that of Anil Sharma, the son of former Chief Minister Sukh Ram.

#Schedule

The Election Commission of India (ECI) announced the election schedule on October 14, 2022. The election was held on November 12, 2022, and the results were announced on December 8, 2022.

#Election statistics

* Total constituencies: 68
* Total voters: 55,92,828 (male: 27,37,845, female: 28,55,039)
* Total polling stations: 7,881
* Total candidates: 412

#Parties and alliances

Several parties and alliances contested the election.

##National Democratic Alliance

The National Democratic Alliance (NDA) consisted of the BJP and the Janata Dal (United).

##United Progressive Alliance

The United Progressive Alliance (UPA) consisted of the INC and the Communist Party of India (Marxist) (CPI(M)).

##Aam Aadmi Party

The Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) contested the election independently.

##Left Front

The Left Front, consisting of the CPI(M) and the Communist Party of India (CPI), contested the election independently.

##Others

Other parties that contested the election included the Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP), the Samajwadi Party (SP), and the Janata Dal (Secular) (JD(S)).

#Candidates

A total of 412 candidates contested the election. The INC fielded 68 candidates, the BJP fielded 65 candidates, the AAP fielded 67 candidates, and the CPI(M) fielded 11 candidates.

#Campaigns

The parties and alliances campaigned extensively, using various methods such as rallies, roadshows, and social media.

##Aam Aadmi Party

The AAP launched its campaign on October 15, 2022, with a rally in Shimla. The party's national convener, Arvind Kejriwal, addressed the rally.

###Manifesto

The AAP released its manifesto on October 25, 2022. The manifesto promised free electricity, free healthcare, and free education to all citizens. It also promised to create 1 lakh jobs in the first year and to increase the minimum support price of crops.

##Bharatiya Janata Party

The BJP launched its campaign on October 20, 2022, with a rally in Kangra. The party's national president, J.P. Nadda, addressed the rally.

###Manifesto

The BJP released its manifesto on October 30, 2022. The manifesto promised to create 2 lakh jobs in the next five years and to increase the minimum support price of crops. It also promised to provide free electricity to all farmers and to increase the pension of old-age pensioners.

##Indian National Congress

The INC launched its campaign on October 25, 2022, with a rally in Mandi. The party's national president, Mallikarjun Kharge, addressed the rally.

###Manifesto

The INC released its manifesto on November 1, 2022. The manifesto promised to create 1 lakh jobs in the first year and to increase the minimum support price of crops. It also promised to provide free electricity to all farmers and to increase the pension of old-age pensioners.

#Surveys and polls

##Exit polls

* An exit poll conducted by the Zee News-BARC on November 12, 2022, predicted that the INC would win 42-48 seats, the BJP would win 20-26 seats, and the AAP would win 1-5 seats.

#Voter turnout

article:
2023 Ligas Departamentales del Perú

The 2023 Ligas Departamentales del Perú was the top division of Peruvian football's amateur leagues, one level below the Liga 2. The tournament was played by teams that won their respective provincial and regional leagues. The winners of each departmental league qualified for the 2024 Copa Perú.

# Liga Departamental de Amazonas

## First stage

The first stage was played by 10 teams, divided into two groups of 5 teams each. The top two teams from each group advanced to the semifinals.

## Quarterfinals

No quarterfinals were played in the Amazonas departmental league.

## Semifinals

The semifinals were played between the top two teams from each group. The winners advanced to the final.

## Final

The final was played between the winners of the semifinals. The champion of the Amazonas departmental league qualified for the 2024 Copa Perú.

2023 Allen, Texas mall shooting

The 2023 Allen, Texas mall shooting was a mass shooting that occurred on May 6, 2023, at the Allen Premium Outlets mall in Allen, Texas, United States. The incident resulted in the deaths of nine people, including the perpetrator, and injured 11 others. The shooting was one of the deadliest in Texas history and sparked widespread outrage and calls for stricter gun control laws.

# Background

The Allen Premium Outlets mall is a popular shopping destination located in the suburb of Allen, Texas, approximately 25 miles north of Dallas. The mall features over 120 stores and restaurants and attracts millions of visitors each year. On the day of the shooting, the mall was crowded with shoppers, including families with children and tourists.

In the months leading up to the shooting, the United States had experienced a surge in mass shootings, with several high-profile incidents occurring across the country. The shootings had sparked renewed debates over gun

article:
2022 United States House of Representatives elections in New York

The 2022 United States House of Representatives elections in New York will be held on November 8, 2022, to elect the 26 U.S. Representatives from the state of New York, one from each of the state's 26 congressional districts. The elections will coincide with the elections for other federal and state offices.

# 2020-22 redistricting controversy

Following the 2020 United States Census, New York lost one congressional seat due to its slow population growth. As a result, the state's congressional districts were redrawn for the 2022 elections. However, the redistricting process was marred by controversy and disputes between Democrats and Republicans over the map's fairness and competitiveness. The map was eventually approved by the New York State Legislature and signed into law by Governor Kathy Hochul.

The 2022 Little League World Series was the 76th edition of the Little League World Series, an annual baseball tournament for children aged 10 to 12 years old, organized by Little League International. The tournament was held from August 17 to August 28, 2022, in South Williamsport, Pennsylvania. The competition featured 16 teams from around the world, divided into two brackets: United States and International.

# Double-elimination stage

article:
Vladimir Putin

Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin has been the dominant figure in Russian politics for over two decades. He has served as the President of Russia since 2012, with the exception of a four-year period from 2008 to 2012, when he served as the Prime Minister due to constitutional term limits. Putin has been widely credited with restoring Russia's influence on the world stage, but his rule has also been marked by authoritarianism, human rights abuses, and a series of high-profile conflicts.

#Early life

Vladimir Putin was born on October 7, 1952, in Leningrad (now Saint Petersburg), Russia, to Vladimir Spiridonovich Putin and Maria Ivanovna Shelomova. His father was a conscript in the Soviet Navy, and his mother was a factory worker. Putin grew up in a communal apartment with his parents and two younger siblings. He developed an interest in sports, particularly judo, and was an average student at school.

#Education

Putin graduated from the Leningrad State University in 1975, where he studied international law. He was a member of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union and was involved in the Komsomol, the youth wing of the party. After graduating, Putin worked for the KGB, the Soviet security agency, for 16 years.

#KGB career

Putin joined the KGB in 1975 and was assigned to the First Chief Directorate, which handled foreign intelligence. He rose through the ranks, becoming a lieutenant colonel by the time he left the KGB in 1990. Putin's KGB career took him to East Germany, where he worked undercover as a diplomat. He was stationed in Dresden, East Germany, from 1985 to 1990, where he gathered intelligence and recruited agents.

#Political career

##1990–1996: Saint Petersburg administration

Putin returned to Leningrad in 1990 and became an advisor to the mayor, Anatoly Sobchak. He helped to promote foreign investment in the city and was involved in the development of the city's infrastructure. In 1994, Putin became the deputy mayor of Saint Petersburg, responsible for foreign economic relations.

##1996–1999: Early Moscow career

In 1996, Putin moved to Moscow and became a deputy to the presidential property manager, Pavel Borodin. He was responsible for managing the Kremlin's property portfolio and was involved in the development of the presidential administration.

##1999: First premiership

In August 1999, Putin became the Prime Minister of Russia, replacing Sergei Stepashin. He was appointed by President Boris Yeltsin, who was looking for a successor. Putin's first few months as prime minister were marked by a series of high-profile terrorist attacks in Moscow and other Russian cities.

##1999–2000: Acting presidency

On December 31, 1999, President Yeltsin resigned, and Putin became the acting president of Russia. He was 47 years old at the time and had been prime minister for just over four months.

##2000–2004: First presidential term

Putin won the presidential election in March 2000, defeating his nearest rival, Gennady Zyuganov, by a margin of over 20%. During his first term, Putin focused on rebuilding the Russian economy, which had been devastated by the 1998 financial crisis. He also launched a series of military campaigns in Chechnya, which had declared independence from Russia in the early 1990s.

##2004–2008: Second presidential term

Putin won re-election in 2004, defeating his nearest rival, Nikolai Kharitonov, by a margin of over 70%. During his second term, Putin continued to consolidate his power, abolishing the direct election of regional governors and reducing the power of the Russian parliament.

##2008–2012: Second premiership

In 2008, Putin stepped down as president due to constitutional term limits and became the prime minister, with Dmitry Medvedev as president. However, it was widely acknowledged that Putin remained the dominant figure in Russian politics.

##2012–2018: Third presidential term

Putin won the presidential election in 2012, defeating his nearest rival, Gennady Zyuganov, by a margin of over 60%. During his third term, Putin continued to consolidate his power, passing a series of laws that restricted civil liberties and cracked down on opposition protests.

###Annexation of Crimea

In 2014, Putin annexed Crimea, a peninsula in Ukraine that had been part of Russia until 1954. The annexation was widely condemned by the international community, and Russia was subjected to a series of economic sanctions.

###Intervention in Syria

In 2015, Putin launched a military intervention in Syria, supporting the government of Bashar al-Assad against rebel forces. The intervention was widely seen as an attempt to reassert Russian influence in the Middle East.

###Russia's interference in the 2016 US election

In 2016, Putin was accused of interfering in the US presidential election, using a series of cyberattacks and propaganda campaigns to support the candidacy of Donald Trump.

##2018–2024: Fourth presidential term

Putin won re-election in 2018, defeating his nearest rival, Pavel Grudinin, by a margin of over 70%. During his fourth term, Putin has continued to consolidate his power, passing a series of laws that restrict civil liberties and crack down on opposition protests.

###COVID-19 pandemic

In 2020, Putin responded to the COVID-19 pandemic by imposing a series of restrictions on public gatherings and travel. He also launched a series of economic measures to support businesses affected by the pandemic.

###Constitutional referendum and amendments

In 2020, Putin held a constitutional referendum, which approved a series of amendments to the Russian constitution. The amendments included a provision that would allow Putin to remain president until 2036.

###Iran trade deal

In 2020, Putin signed a trade deal with Iran, which would increase trade between the two countries by over 50%.

###2021–2022 Russo-Ukrainian crisis

In 2021, Putin launched a series of military maneuvers along the border with Ukraine, sparking a crisis that would eventually lead to a full-scale invasion.

###Full-scale invasion of Ukraine (2022–present)

On February 24, 2022, Putin launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine, which has resulted in thousands of deaths and widespread destruction.

###ICC arrest warrant

In 2023, the International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for Putin, accusing him of war crimes and crimes against humanity.

###2023 Wagner rebellion

In 2023, Putin faced a rebellion by the Wagner Group, a private military company that had been involved in the invasion of Ukraine. The rebellion was eventually put down, but it highlighted the growing instability in Russia.

##2024–present: Fifth presidential term

Putin is widely expected to win re-election in 2024, which would give him a fifth term as president.

#Domestic policies

##Economic, industrial, and energy policies

Putin has pursued a series of economic policies aimed at rebuilding the Russian economy, including the development of the oil and gas industry and the promotion of foreign investment.

##Environmental policy

Putin has been criticized for his environmental policies, which have prioritized economic development over environmental protection.

##Religious policy

Putin has promoted the Russian Orthodox Church, which has been given a privileged position in Russian society.

##Military development

Putin has invested heavily in the Russian military, launching a series of modernization programs aimed at rebuilding the country's armed forces.

##Human rights policy

Putin has been criticized for his human rights record, which has included the suppression of opposition protests and the restriction of civil liberties.

##The media

Putin has exerted significant control over the Russian media, which has been used to promote his policies and suppress opposition.

##Promoting conservatism

Putin has promoted a conservative agenda, which has included the restriction of LGBTQ+ rights and the promotion of traditional values.

##International sporting events

Putin has invested heavily in international sporting events, including the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi and the 2018 World Cup.

#Foreign policy

##Asia

Putin has pursued a series of diplomatic initiatives in Asia, including the development of relations with China and the promotion of the Eurasian Economic Union.

##Post-Soviet states

Putin has pursued a series of policies aimed at reasserting Russian influence in the post-Soviet space, including the annexation of Crimea and the promotion of the Eurasian Economic Union.

##United States, Western Europe, and NATO

Putin has had a tense relationship with the United States, Western Europe, and NATO, which has included the imposition of economic sanctions and the modernization of the Russian military.

##United Kingdom

Putin has had a particularly tense relationship with the United Kingdom, which has included the poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko and the expulsion of Russian diplomats.

###Poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko

In 2006, Putin was accused of ordering the poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko, a former KGB agent who had defected to the United Kingdom.

###Poisoning of Sergei Skripal

In 2018, Putin was accused of ordering the poisoning of Sergei Skripal, a former Russian spy who had defected to the United Kingdom.

Putin has pursued a series of diplomatic initiatives in the Middle East and Africa, including the development of relations with Egypt and the promotion of the Eurasian Economic Union.

#Public image

##Polls and rankings

Putin has consistently ranked as one of the most popular leaders in the world, with high approval ratings in Russia and abroad.

##Cult of personality

Putin has been accused of creating a cult of personality, which has included the promotion of his image and the suppression of opposition.

##Public recognition in the West

Putin has been widely recognized in the West as a dominant figure in international politics, with a series of high-profile appearances and interviews.

##Putinisms

Putin has developed a distinctive style of speaking, which has included the use of colloquialisms and slang.

#Assessments

##After the 2022 invasion of Ukraine

Putin's invasion of Ukraine has been widely condemned by the international community, and his reputation has been damaged as a result.

#Electoral history

Putin has won five presidential elections, with high margins of victory each time.

#Personal life

##Family

Putin has been married to Lyudmila Putina since 1983, and they have two daughters, Maria and Yekaterina.

##Wealth

Putin's wealth is estimated to be over $200 billion, making him one of the richest people in the world.

##Residences

Putin has a number of official and personal residences, including the Kremlin and a dacha in the Moscow suburbs.

###Official government residences

Putin has access to a number of official government residences, including the Kremlin and the White House.

###Personal residences

Putin has a number of personal residences, including a dacha in the Moscow suburbs and a villa in the Black Sea resort town of Sochi.

##Pets

Putin has been known to keep a number of pets, including dogs and horses.

Putin is a member of the Russian Orthodox Church, and has been known to attend church services and promote the church's interests.

Putin is a keen sportsman, and has been known to participate in a number of sports, including judo and hockey.

Clarissa Eden

Clarissa Eden (née Spencer-Churchill) was a British noblewoman and the second wife of Anthony Eden, the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1955 to 1957. She was a member of the prominent Spencer-Churchill family and played a significant role in her husband's life and career.

# Early life

## Paris, Tuscany and London (1937–1939)

Clarissa Spencer-Churchill was born on June 28, 1920, in London, England, to John Spencer-Churchill, the 10th Duke of Marlborough, and his wife, Alexandra Mary Cadogan. She was the younger sister of John Spencer-Churchill, the 11th Duke of Marlborough. The family spent their early years in Paris, where Clarissa's father was the British ambassador. The family later moved to Tuscany, Italy, and finally settled in London.

## Second World War: Oxford and the Foreign Office

During World War II, Clarissa studied at Oxford University, where she met her future husband, Anthony Eden, who was then the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. Clarissa worked at the Foreign Office, where she was tasked with decoding messages and handling confidential documents. Her experience at the Foreign Office gave her a unique understanding of the inner workings of the British government.

## Post-war

After the war, Clarissa continued to work in the Foreign Office, where she became acquainted with many prominent politicians and diplomats. Her experience and knowledge of international affairs made her an invaluable asset to her husband's career.

# 2007 memoir

In 2007, Clarissa published her memoir, "A Memoir: From Churchill to Eden", which provided a unique insight into her life and experiences. The memoir covered her childhood, her marriage to Anthony Eden, and her experiences as the wife of the Prime Minister.

# Friends and acquaintances

## Early admirers

Clarissa was known for her beauty and charm, which attracted many admirers, including the novelist Evelyn Waugh and the poet and politician, Harold Nicolson. Waugh was particularly taken with Clarissa and often sought her opinion on his work.

## Other friends

Clarissa's friends included many prominent figures of the time, including the writer, Nancy Mitford, and the politician, Duff Cooper. Her friendships with these individuals gave her a unique perspective on the social and cultural landscape of post-war Britain.

### Attitudes to the marriage

The couple had three sons together, and their marriage was marked by a deep affection and respect for one another.

When Eden became Prime Minister in 1955, Clarissa became the chatelaine of Downing Street and Chequers, the country house of the Prime Minister. She was responsible for managing the household and entertaining guests, a role she performed with great skill and charm.

## Suez Crisis

The Suez Crisis, which began in 1956, was a major challenge for the Eden government. Clarissa's experience and knowledge of international affairs made her an invaluable asset to her husband during this time. She was often called upon to advise him on matters of state and to provide a unique perspective on the crisis.

Some commentators felt that she was too closely involved in the decision-making process, and that her influence was having a negative impact on the government's policy. Clarissa later recalled that the Suez Canal was "flowing through my drawing room", a phrase that has become synonymous with the crisis.

## Political influence

Some commentators have suggested that her influence was too great, and that she was having a negative impact on the government's policy.

Her influence helped to shield him from criticism and opposition, and she was often called upon to defend him in public.

## Aftermath of Suez

The aftermath of the Suez Crisis was a difficult time for the Eden government. The crisis had damaged the government's reputation and had created a sense of uncertainty and instability. Clarissa's influence helped to steady the ship, and she played a key role in promoting her husband's interests and advancing his career.

### Goldeneye

In the aftermath of the Suez Crisis, Eden's health began to decline. He suffered a series of illnesses, including a bout of jaundice, and he was eventually forced to resign as Prime Minister. Clarissa was by his side throughout this time, and she played a key role in promoting his interests and advancing his career. The couple spent much of their time at Goldeneye, their home in Jamaica, where Eden was able to rest and recover.

Eden's resignation as Prime Minister in 1957 marked the end of an era. Clarissa's influence had been a key factor in his success, and her loyalty and devotion had been unwavering. Despite the challenges and controversies of their time in office, the couple's marriage remained strong, and they continued to support each other in the years that followed.

After his resignation, Eden retired from politics and devoted himself to his writing and his family. Clarissa was by his side throughout this time, and she continued to promote his interests and advance his career. Eden died in 1977, at the age of 79, leaving behind a legacy as one of the most important and influential politicians of the 20th century.

article:
Charles III

Charles III (Charles Philip Arthur George; born November 14, 1948) is the King of the United Kingdom and the other Commonwealth realms. He is the eldest son of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, and has been heir apparent since his mother's accession in 1952.

# Early life, family, and education

Charles was born at Buckingham Palace in London, England, to Princess Elizabeth, Duchess of Edinburgh (now Queen Elizabeth II), and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh. He was christened Charles Philip Arthur George on December 15, 1948, at Buckingham Palace. Charles has three younger siblings: Anne, Prince Andrew, and Prince Edward.

Charles began his education at home, with a governess, before attending Cheam School in Berkshire, England, in 1957. He then attended Gordonstoun School in Moray, Scotland, where his father had also studied. Charles was not a strong student, but he excelled in sports, particularly polo and rugby.

In 1967, Charles attended Trinity College, Cambridge, where he studied archaeology and anthropology. He graduated in 1970 with a 2:2 honors degree. Charles was the first British monarch to earn a university degree.

# Prince of Wales

## Military training and career

After completing his education, Charles undertook military training, beginning with the Royal Air Force (RAF) in 1971. He then attended the Royal Navy's Dartmouth Naval College, where he trained as a naval officer. Charles served on several ships, including the HMS Norfolk and the HMS Minerva, and was commissioned as a sub-lieutenant in 1972.

In 1976, Charles attended the Royal Naval College, Dartmouth, where he trained as a helicopter pilot. He was promoted to captain in 1984 and served as a squadron commander of the 845 Naval Air Squadron. Charles retired from active military service in 1989, but remains a honorary admiral of the Royal Navy.

## Relationships and marriages

### Bachelorhood

Charles was known as a eligible bachelor in his youth, and was linked to several women, including Lady Jane Wellesley and Lady Sarah Spencer. However, he did not marry until he was 32 years old.

### Lady Diana Spencer

Charles met Lady Diana Spencer in 1977, and they became engaged in February 1981. They married on July 29, 1981, at St Paul's Cathedral in London. The couple had two sons, Prince William and Prince Harry, but their marriage was marred by infidelity and media scrutiny. Charles and Diana separated in 1992, and their divorce was finalized in 1996.

### Camilla Parker Bowles

Charles met Camilla Parker Bowles in 1970, and they began an affair in 1981, while Charles was still married to Diana. The affair continued until Diana's death in 1997. Charles and Camilla married on April 9, 2005, at Windsor Guildhall.

## Official duties

As Prince of Wales, Charles undertook numerous official duties, including representing the Queen at state occasions and engagements. He also supported various charitable causes, including conservation and education. Charles was a vocal advocate for architecture and urban planning, and was involved in several high-profile campaigns to preserve historic buildings and landscapes.

# Reign

Charles became King of the United Kingdom and the other Commonwealth realms on September 8, 2022, following the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II. He was proclaimed king by the Accession Council, and was crowned at Westminster Abbey on May 6, 2023.

As king, Charles has continued to support the causes and charities he championed as Prince of Wales. He has also sought to modernize the monarchy, including by reducing the number of working royals and increasing transparency in the royal family's finances.

# Health

Charles has been open about his health struggles, including a bout of coronavirus in 2020. He has also spoken about his experiences with anxiety and depression.

## Diet

# Charity work

Charles has been involved in numerous charitable causes throughout his life, including conservation, education, and healthcare. He has established several charitable organizations, including the Prince's Trust, which supports disadvantaged young people.

## Investigations of donations

In 2020, Charles faced criticism for his acceptance of donations from a convicted sex offender, Jeffrey Epstein. Charles had accepted a donation of £50,000 from Epstein in 2011, which was used to fund a charitable project. Charles denied any wrongdoing, but the incident raised questions about the royal family's vetting of donors.

# Personal interests

Charles has a wide range of personal interests, including architecture, art, and music.

## Built environment

Charles has been a vocal advocate for preserving historic buildings and landscapes. He has been involved in several high-profile campaigns to save historic sites from development, including the Royal Opera House in London.

## Natural environment

Charles has been a long-time supporter of conservation and environmental causes. He has been involved in several initiatives to protect wildlife and promote sustainable agriculture.

## Alternative medicine

Charles has been a vocal advocate for alternative medicine, including homeopathy and acupuncture. He has been involved in several initiatives to promote the use of alternative therapies in the National Health Service.

## Sports

Charles is a keen sportsman, and has been involved in several sporting initiatives, including polo and rugby.

## Visual, performing, and literary arts

Charles has a strong interest in the arts, and has been involved in several initiatives to promote music, dance, and theatre. He has also been a patron of several arts organizations, including the Royal Shakespeare Company.

## Religion and philosophy

Charles has been a vocal advocate for interfaith dialogue and understanding. He has been involved in several initiatives to promote greater understanding between different faiths, including the Prince's Interfaith Dialogue Initiative.

# Media image and public opinion

Charles has been the subject of intense media scrutiny throughout his life, including his relationships and marriages. He has been criticized for his handling of the media, including his decision to give a televised interview in 1995, in which he admitted to infidelity.

## Reaction to press treatment

Charles has been critical of the media's treatment of the royal family, including the intrusion into their personal lives. He has called for greater respect and understanding from the media, and has been involved in several initiatives to promote greater transparency and accountability in the media.

# Residences and finance

Charles has several residences, including Clarence House in London and Highgrove House in Gloucestershire. He also has access to numerous other royal residences, including Sandringham House in Norfolk and Balmoral Castle in Scotland.

# Titles, styles, honours, and arms

## Titles and styles

Charles is known as His Majesty King Charles III. He has held several titles throughout his life, including Prince of Wales and Duke of Cornwall.

## Arms

Charles's coat of arms features the royal arms of the United Kingdom, with the addition of a label of three points, each bearing a fleur-de-lis.

Saw X
================

Saw X is a 2023 American horror film directed by Darren Lynn Bousman and written by Josh Stolberg and Peter Goldfinger. The film is the tenth installment in the Saw franchise and serves as a sequel to the 2020 film Spiral: From the Book of Saw. Saw X continues the story of the Jigsaw Killer's legacy, introducing a new and complex plot that explores the themes of trauma, survival, and the human condition.

Plot
-----

The film takes place several years after the events of Spiral: From the Book of Saw. A new group of characters, all of whom have a connection to the Jigsaw Killer's past, are brought together to participate in a twisted game of survival. As the game unfolds, the players are forced to confront their own demons and work together to uncover the truth behind the Jigsaw Killer's latest creation.

The story centers around a young woman named Abigail, who has been searching for answers about her sister's disappearance for years. Abigail's search leads her to a mysterious location, where she is joined by a group of strangers, each with their own secrets and motivations. As the game begins, the players are subjected to a series of gruesome and deadly challenges, designed to test their physical and mental limits.

Throughout the film, the players are forced to confront their own personal traumas and fears, as they try to survive the game and uncover the truth behind the Jigsaw Killer's latest creation. As the story unfolds, it becomes clear that the game is not just about survival, but about the human condition, and the ways in which people respond to trauma and adversity.

Production

### Development

The film's director, Darren Lynn Bousman, was brought on board to helm the project, marking his return to the Saw franchise after directing several earlier installments.

### Casting

The casting process for Saw X began several months before filming was set to begin. The film's writers and director worked together to select a diverse cast of characters, each with their own unique backstory and motivations. Tobin Bell, who has played the role of Jigsaw in every previous Saw film, was brought back to reprise his role as the iconic villain.

### Filming

Filming for Saw X took place over several months, with a team of experienced crew members working to bring the film's complex and gruesome challenges to life. The film's director, Darren Lynn Bousman, worked closely with the cast and crew to ensure that the film's tone and atmosphere were consistent with the previous Saw installments.

### Post-production

The film's score was composed by a team of experienced musicians, who worked to create a haunting and atmospheric soundtrack that complemented the film's tone and atmosphere.

Release

### Marketing

The film's writers and director worked closely with the marketing team to ensure that the campaign was consistent with the film's tone and atmosphere.

### Theatrical

Saw X was released in theaters on October 27, 2023, with a wide release in the United States and several other countries. The film was released in several different formats, including IMAX and 3D, and was accompanied by a series of promotional events and activities designed to build enthusiasm among fans.

### Home media

Saw X was released on home media several months after its theatrical release, with a Blu-ray and DVD release in several different countries. The film was also released on several different streaming platforms, including Amazon Prime and Netflix.

Reception

### Box office

Saw X was a commercial success, grossing over $100 million at the box office worldwide. The film's opening weekend was particularly strong, with a $30 million opening in the United States.

### Critical response

The critical response to Saw X was mixed, with some critics praising the film's complex and gruesome challenges, while others criticized the film's tone and atmosphere. The film holds a 50% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 20 reviews, with an average rating of 5.5/10.

Sequel
-------

A sequel to Saw X has been announced, with the film's writers and director set to return for another installment in the Saw franchise. The sequel is currently in development, with a release date set for 2025.

2022 in Video Games

The year 2022 saw significant developments and releases in the video game industry. This article provides an overview of the major events, awards, financial performance, and notable releases of the year.

Top-Rated Games

### Major Awards

Several major awards ceremonies took place in 2022 to recognize outstanding achievements in the video game industry. The 2022 Game Awards, presented by Geoff Keighley, honored games such as "Elden Ring" and "God of War Ragnarök". The 2022 Golden Joystick Awards, held in London, awarded "Elden Ring" as the Ultimate Game of the Year. The 2022 DICE Awards, presented by the Academy of Interactive Arts & Sciences, recognized "It Takes Two" as the Game of the Year.

### Critically Acclaimed Games

Several games received widespread critical acclaim in 2022. "Elden Ring", an action role-playing game developed by FromSoftware, received praise for its immersive gameplay and richly detailed world. "God of War Ragnarök", an action-adventure game developed by Santa Monica Studio, was commended for its engaging narrative and improved combat mechanics. "Horizon Forbidden West", an action role-playing game developed by Guerrilla Games, was praised for its stunning visuals and engaging gameplay.

Financial Performance

The global video game market experienced significant growth in 2022, with revenues reaching new heights. According to a report by Newzoo, the global gaming market generated $188.3 billion in revenue in 2022, a 4.6% increase from 2021. The report attributed the growth to the increasing popularity of cloud gaming, cross-platform play, and the rising demand for gaming hardware.

Major Events

### Ukrainian Support

In response to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine, several video game developers and publishers expressed their support for Ukraine. Some companies, such as CD Projekt and GOG.com, announced that they would be donating to Ukrainian charities and relief efforts. Other companies, such as Electronic Arts and Activision Blizzard, suspended sales of their games in Russia and Belarus.

Notable Deaths

Several notable figures in the video game industry passed away in 2022. Isao Takahata, a Japanese video game designer and director, died on April 5, 2022, at the age of 82. Takahata was best known for his work on the "Dragon Quest" series. Hiroshi Yamauchi, a Japanese businessman and former president of Nintendo, died on September 19, 2022, at the age of 85. Yamauchi played a significant role in Nintendo's transition from a playing card manufacturer to a video game developer.

Hardware Releases

Several new gaming hardware devices were released in 2022. The Steam Deck, a handheld gaming device developed by Valve Corporation, was released on February 25, 2022. The device allows users to play PC games on the go. The PlayStation VR2, a virtual reality headset developed by Sony Interactive Entertainment, was announced on January 4, 2022, and is expected to be released in 2023.

Game Releases

### January–March

"Rainbow Six Extraction" was released on January 20, 2022, for PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X/S. "Elden Ring" was released on February 25, 2022, for PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X/S.

### April–June

Several notable games were released in the second quarter of 2022. "Horizon Forbidden West" was released on February 18, 2022, for the PlayStation 4 and PlayStation 5. "Tiny Tina's Wonderlands" was released on March 25, 2022, for PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X/S. "Stray" was released on July 19, 2022, for PC, PlayStation 4, and PlayStation 5. "Soul Hackers 2" was released on August 25, 2022, for PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X/S.

### October–December

Several notable games were released in the fourth quarter of 2022. "Overwatch 2" was released on October 4, 2022, for PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X/S. "Bayonetta 3" was released on October 28, 2022, for the Nintendo Switch. "Godfall" was released on November 9, 2022, for PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X/S.

Video Game-Based Film and Television Releases

2022 Luzon Earthquake

The 2022 Luzon earthquake was a powerful and destructive earthquake that struck the island of Luzon in the Philippines on July 27, 2022. The earthquake caused widespread damage and loss of life, and was felt across the northern part of the country.

# Earthquake

## Characteristics

The earthquake occurred at 8:43 AM local time, with its epicenter located in the town of Lagawe, Abra Province, approximately 400 km north of Manila. The earthquake had a magnitude of 7.0 on the Richter scale, with a depth of 25 km. The Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology (PHIVOLCS) reported that the earthquake was a result of a tectonic plate movement along the Philippine Fault Zone.

## Aftershocks

Following the main earthquake, a series of aftershocks were reported, with some exceeding magnitude 5.0. The aftershocks continued for several days, causing further damage and disrupting rescue efforts.

## Intensity

The earthquake had a maximum intensity of VIII (Severe) on the PHIVOLCS Earthquake Intensity Scale, with reports of buildings collapsing, power lines snapping, and widespread destruction. The intensity of the earthquake was felt as far as Metro Manila, where buildings swayed and people ran for cover.

## Tsunami

A tsunami warning was issued by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) shortly after the earthquake, but it was later lifted as no tsunami waves were reported.

## Liquefaction

Reports of liquefaction were received from several areas, including the town of Lagawe, where the ground turned into a liquid-like state, causing buildings to sink and collapse.

# Response

## International aid

The international community quickly responded to the disaster, with several countries offering aid and assistance to the Philippines. The United States, Japan, and Australia were among the first to offer help, with others following suit.

# Impact

The earthquake had a significant impact on the affected areas, with widespread damage and loss of life reported.

## Abra

The province of Abra was one of the hardest hit, with reports of entire buildings collapsing and widespread destruction. The town of Lagawe was particularly affected, with the town hall and several other buildings collapsing.

## Baguio

The city of Baguio was also severely affected, with reports of buildings collapsing and power lines snapping. The city's famous Burnham Park was damaged, with several trees uprooted and buildings destroyed.

## Ilocos Sur

The province of Ilocos Sur was also affected, with reports of buildings collapsing and widespread damage. The town of Vigan, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, was particularly affected, with several historic buildings damaged.

## Metro Manila

Although Metro Manila was not directly affected by the earthquake, the city's high-rise buildings swayed violently, causing panic among residents and office workers. Several buildings were evacuated as a precautionary measure.

## Elsewhere

Reports of damage and destruction were also received from other areas, including the provinces of La Union, Pangasinan, and Benguet.
